title: Serval and Modulo
statementHtml:
There is an array aa consisting of nn non-negative integers and a magic number kk (k≥1k≥1, kk is an integer). Serval has constructed another array bb of length nn, where bi=aimodkbi=aimodk holds∗∗ for all 1≤i≤n1≤i≤n. Then, he shuffled bb.

You are given the two arrays aa and bb. Find a possible magic number kk. However, there is a small possibility that Serval fooled you, and such an integer does not exist. In this case, output −1−1.

It can be shown that, under the constraints of the problem, if such an integer kk exists, then there exists a valid answer no more than 109109. And you need to guarantee that k≤109k≤109 in your output.

∗∗aimodkaimodk denotes the remainder from dividing aiai by kk.
inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains an integer nn (1≤n≤1041≤n≤104) — the length of the array aa.

The second line contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (0≤ai≤1060≤ai≤106) — the elements of the array aa.

The third line contains nn integers b1,b2,…,bnb1,b2,…,bn (0≤bi≤1060≤bi≤106) — the elements of the array bb.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 104104.
outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, output a single integer kk (1≤k≤1091≤k≤109) — the magic number you found. Print −1−1 if it is impossible to find such an integer.

If there are multiple answers, you may print any of them.
noteHtml:
In the first test case, if k≥3k≥3, then 2=a3modk2=a3modk should be in the array bb, which leads to a contradiction. For k=1k=1, [a1modk,a2modk,a3modk,a4modk]=[0,0,0,0][a1modk,a2modk,a3modk,a4modk]=[0,0,0,0], which cannot be shuffled to bb. For k=2k=2, [a1modk,a2modk,a3modk,a4modk]=[1,1,0,1][a1modk,a2modk,a3modk,a4modk]=[1,1,0,1], which can be shuffled to bb. Thus, the only possible answer is k=2k=2.

In the second test case, note that bb can be obtained by shuffling aa. Thus, all integers between 66 and 109109 are possible answers.

In the third test case, it can be shown that such kk does not exist. Got fooled by Serval!
